column4: Hello! I'm installing Ubuntu right now. I have a disk with 4 partitions: 1 is for Windows, 1 is a backup partition I created a long time ago. 1 is one that I hope I can use for Ubuntu, and I want to have another backup partition. I'm formatting the Ubuntu partition in ext3 with mount point "/", and I want the new backup partition to be fat32. Do I need to put anything special for the mount point for the backup?
don't think so.. I think ubuntu will even add it to fstab automagically.. not sure about it though
Alright :) The main thing is that I want this partition to be accessable in Windows, too. I assume fat32 will do that?
yes
How much do I want to set aside for swap?
my grand grand grand dad told me twice the physical memory.. but that might have changed since then =)
not really... up to 1G would be more than enough.. it will just get terribly slow if you need more swap
primary I'd think
I don't know what the terms mean :( I've set up the partition I'm installing Ubuntu onto as primary
primary partitions are single partitions, you can only have 4 per drive I think.. logical partitions can have more partitions inside so you can have more than 4 partitions
huh? code name?
space after fdisk... "fdisk -l"
afaik ubuntu can resize ntfs.. I think it can even do it from the installer.. is the partition mounted?
tried sudo with that?
you could try testdisk.. but read the manual first.. if you do something wrong you might end up destroying the data
might be because the c program does something bad.. what kind of c program is it?
try running the c program with "nice" or "ionice" and see if that makes any difference.. it might not be about the c program at all but it's worth a try
ah.. good..
I would look into your program.. if you've got the source code.. perhaps it can be modified to be more friendly to the rest of the system
or just remember to run it with "nice"
oh.. I'm not very good with c.. you could ask in ##c or perhaps in ##programming
just ask your question
